title: pages
description: Nuxt provides a file-based routing to create routes within your web application.

children.value: Nuxt provides a file-based routing to create routes within your web application using
won't be included if you only use
Pages are Vue components and can have the
file will be mapped to the
component to display the current page:
<!-- Markup shared across all pages, ex: NavBar -->
must have a single root element
to allow route transitions between pages. (HTML comments are considered elements as well.)

This means that when the route is server-rendered, or statically generated, you will be able to see its contents correctly, but when you navigate towards that route during client-side navigation the transition between routes will fail and you'll see that the route will not be rendered.
Here are some examples to illustrate what a page with a single root element looks like:
<!-- This page correctly has only one single root element -->
<!-- This page will not render when route changes during client side navigation, because of this comment -->
>And will not render when route changes during client side navigation</
If you place anything within square brackets, it will be turned into a
parameter. You can mix and match multiple parameters and even non-dynamic text within a file name or directory.
If you want a parameter to be
, you must enclose it in double square brackets - for example,

props.code:
-| pages/
---| index.vue
---| users-[group]/
-----| [id].vue

children.value: Given the example above, you can access group/id within your component via the

props.code: admins - 123

children.value: If you want to access the route using Composition API, there is a global
function that will allow you to access the route just like

props.code:
<script setup>
const route = useRoute()

if (route.params.group === 'admins' && !route.params.id) {
  console.log('Warning! Make sure user is authenticated!')
}
</script>

children.value: If you need a catch-all route, you create it by using a file named like

props.code: ["hello", "world"]

-| pages/
---| parent/
------| child.vue
---| parent.vue

If you want more control over when the
component is re-rendered (for example, for transitions), you can either pass a string or function via the
prop, or you can define a

props.code:
<script setup>
definePageMeta({
  key: route => route.fullPath
})
</script>

children.value: You might want to define metadata for each route in your app. You can do this using the
macro, which will work both in

props.code:
<script setup>
definePageMeta({
  title: 'My home page'
})
</script>

children.value: This data can then be accessed throughout the rest of your app from the

props.code:
<script setup>
const route = useRoute()

console.log(route.meta.title) // My home page
</script>

children.value: If you are using nested routes, the page metadata from all these routes will be merged into a single object. For more on route meta, see the

. It will be compiled away so you cannot reference it within your component. Instead, the metadata passed to it will be hoisted out of the component. Therefore, the page meta object cannot reference the component (or values defined on the component). However, it can reference imported bindings.

props.code:
<script setup>
import { someData } from '~/utils/example'

const title = ref('')

definePageMeta({
  title,  // This will create an error
  someData
})
</script>

You can define page aliases. They allow you to access the same page from different paths. It can be either a string or an array of strings as defined
Nuxt will automatically wrap your page in
. This might be useful to do, for example, in a parent route that has dynamic child routes, if you want to preserve page state across route changes.
When your goal is to preserve state for parent routes use this syntax:
. You can also set props to be passed to
You can set a default value for this property
You can define the layout used to render the route. This can be either false (to disable any layout), a string or a ref/computed, if you want to make it reactive in some way.
You can define transition properties for the
component that wraps your pages and layouts, or pass
wrapper for that route. You can see a list of options that can be passed
You can set default values for these properties

You can define middleware to apply before loading this page. It will be merged with all the other middleware used in any matching parent/child routes. It can be a string, a function (an anonymous/inlined middleware function following
You may define a name for this page's route.
You may define a path matcher, if you have a more complex pattern than can be expressed with the file name. See
If you add custom metadata for your pages, you may wish to do so in a type-safe way. It is possible to augment the type of the object accepted by
// It is always important to ensure you import/export something when augmenting a type
To navigate between pages of your app, you should use the
This component is included with Nuxt and therefore you don't have to import it as you do with other components.

props.code:
<template>
  <NuxtLink to="/">Home page</NuxtLink>
</template>

children.value: This is the recommended way to specify router options.

You can optionally override routes using a function that accepts scanned routes and returns customized routes.
If returning
, Nuxt will fallback to the default routes. (useful to modify input array)
Nuxt will not augment any new routes you return from the
of the component you provide. If you want that to happen, you should probably use the

You can optionally override history mode using a function that accepts base url and returns history mode.
If returning
, Nuxt will fallback to the default history.
Only JSON serializable options are configurable:
You can enable hash history in SPA mode. In this mode, router uses a hash character (#) before the actual URL that is internally passed. When enabled, the
URL is never sent to the server
Nuxt will create a route for all files ending with one of the
You can change or remove pages from the scanned routes with the
nuxt hook. For example, to prevent creating routes for any
Nuxt 3 allows programmatic navigation through the

utility method. Using this utility method, you will be able to programmatically navigate the user in your app. This is great for taking input from the user and navigating them dynamically throughout your application. In this example, we have a simple method called
that gets called when the user submits a search form.
or chain its result by returning from functions.

props.code:
<script setup>
const router = useRouter();
const name = ref('');
const type = ref(1);

function navigate(){
  return navigateTo({
    path: '/search',
    query: {
      name: name.value,
      type: type.value
    }
  })
}
</script>
